name: myself
content:

A2 used when the subject of the verb is "I" and the object is the same person: I bought myself a new coat. I caught sight of myself in the mirror. Yes, I thought to myself, it's time to take a holiday.
B2 used to emphasize "I" as the subject of a sentence: I myself don't like a heavy meal at lunchtime. I don't like a heavy meal at lunchtime myself.
used instead of "I" or "me": My husband and myself were delighted with the gift. They very kindly invited my sister and myself to the inauguration. (all) by myself
alone or without help from anyone else: I live by myself . I had to do the whole job all by myself . I'm ashamed to say I ate the whole plateful all by myself. Are you going to leave me all by myself? I don't especially like travelling by myself. I managed to take a shower by myself for the first time since the operation. I can't move all those boxes by myself. (all) to myself
for my use only: I never get an hour to myself. I had a couple of hours to myself between appointments so I thought I'd visit the cathedral. I usually get an hour or so to myself before the rest of the family get up and I love it. I had a double room all to myself and it was wonderful. For half an hour I had the whole pool to myself. So I get to have you all to myself this evening, do I? not be myself (UK also not feel myself); (US also not feel like myself)
not to be or feel as happy or as healthy as usual: I'm sure you're aware that I haven't been myself lately. I went to see the doctor because I haven't been quite myself lately. I'm normally pretty upbeat but I really haven't felt myself since the news.US I don't know how else to put it except that I haven't been feeling like myself. Since the accident I haven't felt myself.US I thought I was doing better, but I still don't quite feel like myself yet. in myself
UK informal used when describing your state of mind when you are physically ill: I'm well enough in myself (= happy) - I've just got this nagging headache.

the person speaking; the reflexive form of I: I found myself addressing a tall elegant man in his mid-forties.
Myself is sometimes used to emphasize I as the subject of a sentence: I myself prefer to skip lunch.
Myself is sometimes used instead of I or me: They very kindly invited my sister and myself to the party. I live by myself (= alone) in a small apartment in Brooklyn. I had to do the whole job (all) by myself (= alone and without help from anyone). I just need some time to myself (= for my own use).
